sectionBreak.stem:
The homogeneous set of equations for a three mass–four spring system with m's = 40 kg and the k's = 240 N/m between two fixed walls is as follows:

 

 

%media:formula92.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
For three springs

 

%media:formula98.mml%

 

 

Substituting m = 40 kg and k = 240 gives

 

%media:formula96.mml%

 

The determinant is –ω6 +36ω4 – 360ω2 + 864 = 0, which can be solved for ω2 = 20.4853, 12, and 3.5147s–2. Therefore  the frequencies are ω = 4.526, 3.464, and 1.875 s–1.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the procedure to determine the determinant value from the set of equations?

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How to apply the power method in MATLAB using basic operations?

worksheet.stem:
Use the power method to determine the highest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector for the system given below.

 

%media:formula1.mml%

 

The highest eigenvalue is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The corresponding eigenvector is __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The system and the initial guesses can be set up as

 

>> format short g
>> a=[2 8 10;8 4 5;10 5 7];
>> x=[1 1 1]';

 

 

First iteration:
>> x=a*x
x =
    20
    17
    22
>> e=max(x)
e =
    22
>> x=x/e
x =
    0.90909
    0.77273
    1.0000

 

Second iteration:
>> x=a*x
x =
    18.0000
    15.364
    19.955
>> e=max(x)
e =
    19.955
>> x=x/e
x =
    0.90205
    0.76993
    1.0000

 

Third iteration:
>> x=a*x
x =
    17.964
    15.2964
    19.870
>> e=max(x)
e =
    19.870
>> x=x/e
x =
    0.90405
    0.7698
    1.0000

 

Fourth iteration:
>> x=a*x
x =
    17.967
    15.312
    19.889
>> e=max(x)
e =
    19.889
>> x=x/e
x =
    0.90332
    0.76983
    1.0000

 

Thus, after four iterations, the result is converging on the highest eigenvalue. After several more iterations, it will converge on an eigenvalue of 19.884 with a corresponding eigenvector of [0.90351 0.76983 1].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How to apply the power method in MATLAB using basic operations?

worksheet.stem:
Use the power method to determine the lowest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector for the below system. 

 

%media:formula2.mml%

 

The lowest eigenvalue is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The corrsponding eigenvector is __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following script can be developed to determine the smallest eigenvalue with the power method. The script is set up to compute 4 iterations:

 

>> clear, clc, format short g
>> a=[2 8 10;8 4 5;10 5 7];
>> ai = inv(a)
>> x=[1 1 1]';
>> for i = 1:4
>> disp('Iteration:')
>> x=ai*x
>> e=max(x)
>> x=x/e
>> end
>> xn=x/norm(x)

 

 

The results are

 

ai =
    -0.071429    0.14286    -8.3267e-017
      0.14286    2.0476     -1.6667
            0   -1.6667      1.3333

 

Iteration:
x =
    0.071429
    0.52381
   -0.33333
e =
    0.52381
x =
    0.13636
    1
   -0.63636

 

Iteration:
x =
    0.13312
    3.1277
   -2.5152
e =
    3.1277
x =
    0.042561
    1
   -0.80415

 

Iteration:
x =
    0.13982
    3.394
   -2.7389
e =
    3.394
x =
    0.041196
    1
   -0.80699

 

Iteration:
x =
    0.13991
    3.3985
   -2.7426
e =
    3.3985
x =
    0.04117
    1
   -0.80702
xn =
    0.032022
    0.7778
   -0.6277

 

Thus, after four iterations, the estimate of the lowest eigenvalue is 1/(3.3985) = 0.29424 with a normalized eigenvector of [0.032022 0.7778 –0.6277].

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which is the built-in MATLAB function to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Derive the set of differential equations for a three mass–four spring system (see the figure) that describes their time motion. Write the three differential equations in matrix form


{Acceleration vector} + [k/m matrix]{displacement vector x} = 0

 

%media:13-4.png%


Note each equation has been divided by the mass. Solve for the eigenvalues and natural frequencies for the following values of mass and spring constants: k1 = k4 = 15 N/m, k2 = k3 = 35 N/m, and m1 = m2 = m3 = 1.5 kg. (Round the final answers to four decimal places and write them as displayed in MATLAB)

 

Eigenvalues are __ANS1__, __ANS2__, and __ANS3__.

 

Natural frequencies are __ANS4__,  __ANS5__, and  __ANS6__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
By summing forces on each mass and equating that to the mass times acceleration, the resulting differential equations can be written as

 

%media:formula3.mml%

 

%media:formula4.mml%

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

 

In matrix form,

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

 

Using k1 = k4 = 15 N/m, k2 = k3 = 35 N/m, and m1 = m2 = m3 = 1.5 kg, the k/m matrix becomes

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

 

Solve for the eigenvalues/natural frequencies using MATLAB:

 

>> k1=15;k4=15;k2=35;k3=35;
>> m1=1.5;m2=1.5;m3=1.5;
>> a=[(k1+k2)/m1 -k2/m1 0;-k2/m2 (k2+k3)/m2 -k3/m2;0 -k3/m3 (k3+k4)/m3];
>> w2=eig(a)
w2 =
    6.3350
   33.3333
   73.6650
>> w=sqrt(w2)
w =
    2.5169
    5.7735
    8.5828

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Consider the mass-spring system in the figure. The frequencies for the mass vibrations can be determined by solving for the eigenvalues and by applying %media:formula8.mml% which yields

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

Applying the guess x = x0eiωt as a solution, we get the following matrix:

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

%media:13-5.png%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
Here is a MATLAB session that uses eig to determine the eigenvalues and the natural frequencies:

 

>> k=2;
>> kmw2=[2*k,-k,-k;-k,2*k,-k;-k,-k,2*k];
>> [v,d]=eig(kmw2)
v =
   0.5774    0.7634    0.2895
   0.5774   -0.6325    0.5164
   0.5774   -0.1310   -0.8059
d =
   0.0000       0        0
   0       6.0000        0
   0            0   6.0000

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which is the built-in MATLAB function to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

multipleChoice.stem: Use MATLAB’s eig command to solve for the eigenvalues of the k − mω2 matrix given below. Let m1 = m2 = m3 = 1 kg, and k = 2 N/m.
multipleChoice.commonFeedback:
Here is a MATLAB session that uses eig to determine the eigenvalues and the natural frequencies:

 

>> k=2;
>> kmw2=[2*k,-k,-k;-k,2*k,-k;-k,-k,2*k];
>> [v,d]=eig(kmw2)
v =
   0.5774    0.7634    0.2895
   0.5774   -0.6325    0.5164
   0.5774   -0.1310   -0.8059
d =
   0.0000       0        0
   0       6.0000        0
   0            0   6.0000

property.value:
From the previous problem, the eigenvalues are 0, 6, and 6.

Setting these eigenvalues equal to mω2, the three frequencies can be obtained.

 

%media:formula12.mml%

 

%media:formula13.mml%

 

%media:formula14.mml%

sectionBreak.stem:
%media:13-6.png%

 

As displayed in the figure, an LC circuit can be modeled by the following system of differential equations:

 

%media:formula50.mml%

 

%media:formula51.mml%

 

%media:formula52.mml%

 

where L = inductance (H), t = time (s), i = current (A), and C = capacitance (F).

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The first eigenvalue is 0.1981 with eigenvector [– 0.7370  – 0.5910  – 0.3280].

The second eigenvalue is 1.5550 with eigenvector [– 0.5910  0.3280  0.7370].

The third eigenvalue is 3.2470 with eigenvector [0.3280  – 0.7370  0.5910].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which is the built-in MATLAB function to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Assuming that a solution is of the form ij = Ij sin(ωt), determine the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for this system with L = 1 H and C = 0.25 F. 

 

The first eigenvalue is __ANS1__ with eigenvector __ANS2__.

 

The second eigenvalue is __ANS3__ with eigenvector __ANS4__.

 

The third eigenvalue is __ANS5__ with eigenvector __ANS6__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The solution along with its second derivative can be substituted into the simultaneous ODEs. After simplification, the result is

 

%media:formula53.mml%

 

Thus, we have formulated an eigenvalue problem. Further simplification results for the special case where the C’s and L’s are constant. For this situation, the system can be expressed in matrix form as

 

%media:formula54.mml%

 

where λ = LCω2. MATLAB can be employed to determine values for the eigenvalues and eigenvectors

​

>> a=[1 -1 0; -1 2 -1; 0 -1 2];
>> [v,d]=eig(a)

 

v =

   -0.7370   -0.5910    0.3280
   -0.5910    0.3280   -0.7370
   -0.3280    0.7370    0.5910


d =

    0.1981         0         0
         0    1.5550         0
         0         0    3.2470


The matrix v consists of the system’s three eigenvectors (arranged as columns), and d is a matrix with the corresponding eigenvalues on the diagonal. Thus, the package computes that the eigenvalues are λ = 0.1981, 1.555, and 3.247.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
%media:13-7.png%

 

As displayed in the figure, an LC circuit can be modeled by the following system of differential equations:

 

%media:formula55.mml%

 

%media:formula95.mml%

 

where L = inductance (H), t = time (s), i = current (A), and C = capacitance (F).

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The first eigenvalue is 0.3820 with eigenvector [–0.8507 –0.5257].

The second eigenvalue is 2.6180 with eigenvector [–0.5257 0.8507].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which built-in MATLAB function can be used to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Assuming that a solution is of the form ij = Ij sin(ωt), determine the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for this system with L = 1 H and C = 0.25 F. 

 

The first eigenvalue is __ANS1__ with eigenvector __ANS2__.

 

The second eigenvalue is __ANS3__ with eigenvector __ANS4__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The solution along with its second derivative can be substituted into the simultaneous ODEs. After simplification, the result is

 

%media:formula57.mml%

 

Thus, we have formulated an eigenvalue problem. Further simplification results for the special case where the C’s and L’s are constant. For this situation, the system can be expressed in matrix form as

 

%media:formula58.mml%

 

A package like MATLAB can be used to evaluate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors as in


>> a=[1 -1;-1 2];
>> [v,d]=eig(a)
v =
   -0.8507   -0.5257
   -0.5257    0.8507
d =
   0.3820         0
        0    2.6180


Thus, we can see that the eigenvalues are λ = 0.382 and 2.618. The eigenvectors tell us that these correspond to oscillations that coincide (–0.8507 –0.5257) and which run counter to each other (–0.5257 0.8507).

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Engineers and scientists use mass-spring models to gain insight into the dynamics of structures under the influence of disturbances such as earthquakes. The given figure shows such a model for a two-story building. Each floor mass is represented by mi, and each floor stiffness is represented by ki for i = 1 to 2.

 

%media:13-8.png%

 

For this case, the analysis is limited to horizontal motion of the structure as it is subjected to horizontal base motion due to earthquakes.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which built-in MATLAB function can be used to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

hint.name: hint #2
hint.value: How are the frequencies related to eigenvalues?

worksheet.stem:
Using MATLAB, determine the eigenvalues and the resonant frequencies for the given system. (Round the final answers to four decimal places and write them as appeared in MATLAB.)

 

The eigenvalues are __ANS1__ and __ANS2__. 

 

The resonant frequencies are __ANS3__ and __ANS4__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Force balances can be written as

 

%media:formula11.mml%

%media:formula17.mml%

 

Assume solutions

 

%media:formula19.mml%

 

 

Substitute

 

%media:formula20.mml%

 

%media:formula23.mml%

 

 

Cancel sin(ωt) and collect terms

 

%media:formula24.mml%

 

%media:formula25.mml%

 

 

Substitute parameters

 

%media:formula26.mml%

 

%media:formula27.mml%

 

 

MATLAB solution:


>> A=[450 -200;-240 240];
>> [v,d]=eig(A)
>> wn=sqrt(diag(d))'/2/pi


v =
    0.8232   0.4983
   -0.5678   0.8670
 

d =
    587.9506          0
           0   102.0494
 

wn =
    3.8591   1.6078

Engineers and scientists use mass-spring models to gain insight into the dynamics of structures under the influence of disturbances such as earthquakes. worksheet.stem:
Using MATLAB, determine the eigenvalues and the resonant frequencies for the given system. (Round the final answers to four decimal places and write them as displayed in MATLAB.)

 

The eigenvalues are __ANS1__, __ANS2__, __ANS3__, and __ANS4__. 

 

The resonant frequencies are __ANS5__, __ANS6__, __ANS7__, and __ANS8__.

Force balances can be written as

 

%media:formula28.mml%

 

%media:formula29.mml%

 

%media:formula30.mml%

 

%media:formula31.mml%

 

 

Assume solutions

 

%media:formula32.mml%

 

 

Substitute

 

%media:formula33.mml%

 

%media:formula34.mml%

 

%media:formula35.mml%

 

%media:formula36.mml%

 

 

Cancel sin(ωt) and collect terms

 

%media:formula37.mml%

 

%media:formula38.mml%

 

%media:formula39.mml%

 

%media:formula40.mml%

 

 

Substitute parameters

 

%media:formula41.mml%

 

%media:formula42.mml%

sectionBreak.stem:
The curvature of a slender column subject to an axial load P (see the figure) can be modeled by

 

%media:formula45.mml%

 

where

 

%media:formula46.mml%

 

where E = the modulus of elasticity, and I = the moment of inertia of the cross section about its neutral axis. This model can be converted into an eigenvalue problem by substituting a centered finite-difference approximation for the second derivative to give

 

%media:formula47.mml%

 

where i = a node located at a position along the rod’s interior, and Δx = the spacing between nodes. This equation can be expressed as

 

%media:formula48.mml%

 

Writing this equation for a series of interior nodes along the axis of the column yields a homogeneous system of equations. For example, if the column is divided into five segments (i.e., four interior nodes), the result is

 

%media:formula49.mml%

 

An axially loaded wooden column has the following characteristics: E = 10×109 Pa, I =1.25×10–5 m4, and L = 3m.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
For four interior points (h = 3/5), the resulting system of equations is

 

%media:formula59.mml%

 

Setting the determinant equal to zero and expanding it gives (2 − 0.36p2)4 − 3(2 − 0.36p2)2 +1 = 0 which can be solved for the first four eigenvalues

​p = ±1.0301
p = ±1.9593
p = ±2.6967
p = ±3.1702

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The first eigenvalue is 1.0610 with eigenvector [0.3717 0.6015 0.6015 0.3717].

The second eigenvalue is 3.8388 with eigenvector [–0.6015 –0.3717 0.3717 0.6015].

The third eigenvalue is 7.2723 with eigenvector [–0.6015 0.3717 0.3717 –0.6015].

The fourth eigenvalue is 10.0501 with eigenvector [–0.3717 0.6015 –0.6015 0.3717].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which built-in MATLAB function can be used to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
For the five-segment and four-node representation, use the MATLAB eig function to determine the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

 

The first eigenvalue is __ANS1__ with eigenvector __ANS2__.

 

The second eigenvalue is __ANS3__ with eigenvector __ANS4__.

 

The third eigenvalue is __ANS5__ with eigenvector __ANS6__.

 

The fourth eigenvalue is __ANS7__ with eigenvector __ANS8__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The system can be normalized so that the coefficient of the eigenvalue is unity:

 

%media:formula60.mml%

 

 

MATLAB solution:

 

>> A=[5.5556 -2.7778 0 0;-2.7778 5.5556 -2.7778 0; ...
0 -2.7778 5.5556 -2.7778;0 0 -2.7778 5.5556];
>> [v,d]=eig(A)
>> wn=sqrt(diag(d))'

v =

    0.3717   -0.6015   -0.6015   -0.3717
    0.6015   -0.3717    0.3717    0.6015
    0.6015    0.3717    0.3717   -0.6015
    0.3717    0.6015   -0.6015    0.3717


d =

    1.0610         0         0         0
         0    3.8388         0         0
         0         0    7.2723         0
         0         0         0   10.0501


wn =

    1.0301    1.9593    2.6967    3.1702

The corresponding eigenvector is [0.6015 –0.3717 –0.3717 0.6015].

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which built-in MATLAB function can be used to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
For the five-segment and four-node representation, use the power method to determine the largest eigenvalue and its corresponding eigenvector. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The largest eigenvalue is __ANS1__.

 

The corresponding eigenvector is __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Power method:

 

>> clear, clc, format short g
>> A=[5.5556 -2.7778 0 0;-2.7778 5.5556 -2.7778 0; ...
0 -2.7778 5.5556 -2.7778;0 0 -2.7778 5.5556];
>> x=[1 1 1 1]';
>> for i = 1:4
 >> disp('Iteration:')
 >> x=A*x
 >> e=max(x)
  >> x=x/e
>> end
>> xn=x/norm(x)

 


The 4 iterations are

 

Iteration:
x =
   2.7778
        0
        0
   2.7778
e =
   2.7778
x =
   1
   0
   0
   1
Iteration:
x =
   5.5556
  -2.7778
  -2.7778
   5.5556
e =
   5.5556
x =
   1.0000
  -0.5000
  -0.5000
   1.0000
Iteration:
x =
   6.9445
  -4.1667
  -4.1667
  6.9445
e =
   6.9445
x =
   1.0000
  -0.6000
  -0.6000
   1.0000
Iteration:
x =
   7.2223
  -4.4445
  -4.4445
   7.2223
e =
   7.2223
x =
   1.0000
  -0.6154
  -0.6154
   1.0000
xn =
   0.6022
  -0.3706
  -0.3706
   0.6022

 

If the process is continued, the result for the maximum eigenvalue is p = 7.2724 with an associated eigenvector [0.6015 –0.3717 –0.3717 0.6015].

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
A system of two homogeneous linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients can be written as

 

%media:formula61.mml%

 

%media:formula62.mml%

 

 

If you have taken a course in differential equations, you know that the solutions for such equations have the form

 

%media:formula63.mml%

 

where c and λ are constants to be determined. Substituting this solution and its derivative into the original equations converts the system into an eigenvalue problem. The resulting eigenvalues and eigenvectors can then be used to derive the general solution to the differential equations. For example, for the two-equation case, the general solution can be written in terms of vectors as

 

%media:formula64.mml%

 

where {vi} = the eigenvector corresponding to the ith eigenvalue (λi) and the c’s are unknown coefficients that can be determined with the initial conditions.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

The eigenvalues are __ANS1__ and __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The assumed solutions and their derivatives can be substituted into the original differential equations to give

 

%media:formula65.mml%

 

%media:formula66.mml%

 

 

Cancelling the exponentials and rearranging converts the system into an eigenvalue problem

 

%media:formula67.mml%

 

%media:formula68.mml%

 

 

The characteristic equation is

 

%media:formula69.mml%

 

which can be solved for the eigenvalues

 

%media:formula70.mml%​

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which built-in MATLAB function can be used to find the eigenvalues of a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Use MATLAB to solve for the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

 

The first eigenvalue is __ANS1__ with eigenvectors __ANS2__.

 

The second eigenvalue is __ANS3__ with eigenvectors __ANS4__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The eig function can be used to determine the same result as (a) as well as to obtain the associated eigenvectors:

 

>> clear,clc,clf,format long g
>> A=[-5 3;100 -301];
>> p=poly(A)
>> d=roots(p)
>> [v,d]=eig(A)

p =

                         1                       306                      1205


d =

         -302.010066774027
         -3.98993322597295

 

v =
   0.947724927231108   -0.010100152527012
   0.319088486637782    0.999948992158566


d =
  -3.98993322597295                   0
                  0   -302.010066774027

The solution can then be written as

 

%media:formula71.mml%

 

The unknown constants are evaluated by applying the initial conditions to the previous equation at t = 0,

The above equation can be solved for

 

>> y0 = [50 100]';
>> c = v\y0
c =
53.6412825029131
82.8879122783221

 

The above values can be substituted back into the solution to give

 

%media:formula73.mml%

 

which yields the final solution

doc.stem:
%media:13-12.png%

 

Water flows between the North American Great Lakes as depicted in the figure. Based on mass balances, the following differential equations can be written for the concentrations in each of the lakes for a pollutant that decays with first-order kinetics:

 

%media:formula86.mml%

 

%media:formula87.mml%

 

%media:formula88.mml%

 

%media:formula89.mml%

 

%media:formula90.mml%

 

where k = the first-order decay rate (/yr), which is equal to 0.69315/(half-life). Note that the constants in each of the equations account for the flow between the lakes. Due to the testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, the concentrations of strontium-90 (90Sr) in the five lakes in 1963 were approximately {c} = {17.7 30.5 43.9 136.3 30.1}T in units of Bq/m3. Assuming that no additional 90Sr entered the system thereafter, use MATLAB to compute the concentrations in each of the lakes from 1963 through 2010. Note that 90Sr has a half-life of 28.8 years.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem: The power method is an iterative approach that can be employed to determine the largest or dominant eigenvalue. With slight modification, it can also be employed to determine the smallest value. It has the additional benefit that the corresponding eigenvector is obtained as a by-product of the method.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function to determine the largest eigenvalue and its associated eigenvector with the power method.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required for the function to determine the largest eigenvalue and its associated eigenvector with the power method?

worksheet.stem:
The homogeneous set of equations for a three mass–four spring system between two fixed walls is as follows:

 

%media:formula91.mml%

 

If all the masses m = 1 kg and all the spring constants k = 20 N/m, the find the largest eigenvalue and its associated eigenvector using the M-file.

 

The highest eigenvalue is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The corresponding eigenvector is __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
If all the masses m = 1 kg and all the spring constants k = 20 N/m, the system can be expressed in the matrix format |A – λ[I]| = 0 as

 

%media:formula93.mml%

 

where the eigenvalue λ is the square of the angular frequency ω2.

 

 

Following is the MATLAB code to determine the largest eigenvalue and its associated eigenvector with power method.

 

function [eval, evect,ea,iter] = powereig(A,es,maxit)
%Power method for largest eigenvalue
% input:
% es = desired relative error (default = 0.0001%)
% maxit = maximum allowable iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% eval = largest eigenvalue
% evect = largest eigenvector
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
if nargin<1,error('at least 1 input argument required'),end
if nargin<2|isempty(es), es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3|isempty(maxit), maxit=50;end
format short g
n=length(A);
vect=ones(n,1);
val=0;iter=0;ea=100;
while(1)
    valold=val;
    vect=A*vect;
    val=max(abs(vect));
    vect=vect./val;
    iter=iter+1;
    if val~=0, ea = abs((val-valold)/val)*100; end
    if ea<=es | iter >= maxit,break,end
end
eval=val;evect=vect;
end

 

 

Here is the MATLAB session for the given problem.

 

>> A=[40 -20 0;-20 40 -20;0 -20 40];
>> [eval,evect,ea,iter] = powereig(A)
>> evect=evect/norm(evect)
>> [v,d]=eig(A)

eval =

       68.284


evect =

      0.70711
           -1
      0.70711


ea =

   5.1534e-05


iter =

    11


evect =

          0.5
     -0.70711
          0.5


v =

          0.5     -0.70711         -0.5
      0.70711  -8.3135e-18      0.70711
          0.5      0.70711         -0.5


d =

       11.716            0            0
            0           40            0
            0            0       68.284

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to calculate the eigenvalue?

worksheet.stem:
Use the M-file to determine the highest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector for the following matrix.

 

%media:formula94.mml%

 

The highest eigenvalue is __ANS1__. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The corresponding eigenvector is __ANS2__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Following is the MATLAB code to determine the largest eigenvalue and its associated eigenvector with power method.

 

function [eval, evect,ea,iter] = powereig(A,es,maxit)
%Power method for largest eigenvalue
% input:
% es = desired relative error (default = 0.0001%)
% maxit = maximum allowable iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% eval = largest eigenvalue
% evect = largest eigenvector
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
if nargin<1,error('at least 1 input argument required'),end
if nargin<2|isempty(es), es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3|isempty(maxit), maxit=50;end
format short g
n=length(A);
vect=ones(n,1);
val=0;iter=0;ea=100;
while(1)
    valold=val;
    vect=A*vect;
    val=max(abs(vect));
    vect=vect./val;
    iter=iter+1;
    if val~=0, ea = abs((val-valold)/val)*100; end
    if ea<=es | iter >= maxit,break,end
end
eval=val;evect=vect;
end

 

Here is the MATALAB session for the given problem.

 

>> clear,clc

>>  A=[2 8 10;8 4 5;10 5 7];
>> [eval, evect,ea,iter] = powereig(A)
>> evect=evect/norm(evect)
>> [v,d]=eig(A)

 

eval =

       19.884


evect =

      0.90351
      0.76983
            1


ea =

   7.9461e-05


iter =

    11


evect =

      0.58213
      0.49599
       0.6443


v =

     -0.81247    -0.032022      0.58213
      0.38603      -0.7778      0.49599
      0.43689       0.6277       0.6443


d =

      -7.1785            0            0
            0      0.29424            0
            0            0       19.884
